title: analysis chosen heirs resignation leaves angela merkels succession
story: Angela Merkel’s carefully laid plans for her succession lay in ruins on Monday, as her chosen heir, Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, announced that she was standing down.It was always going to be a gamble when Mrs Merkel decided to split the roles of chancellor and party leader in order to prolong her own time in power. But few expected it to be Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer whose career was cut short. Back then, the risk was all thought to be on Mrs Merkel’s part.It is a measure of how far Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer, or AKK as she likes to be known, has fallen from grace that her announcement on Monday that she would not lead her party into next year’s election had an air of inevitability about it.Back in 2018, she used to be known as mini-Merkel. But the nickname has disappeared as the expectation she could live up to her mentor's example has faded.In just over a year as Christian Democrat (CDU) leader she has lurched from gaffe to gaffe and the party has continued its inexorable slide in the polls.But it was last week’s debacle in Thuringia, when CDU politicians defied her and broke the party’s traditional “firewall” against the far-Right to vote alongside the nationalist Alternative for Germany party (AfD), that finished Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer.She claimed on Monday she was stepping down because some in the CDU were not prepared to delineate the party strongly enough against the AfD and the Left party.But the truth, harsh though it may sound, is that she just wasn’t up to the job. That was clear last week as she foundered for a response to the Thuringian crisis and Mrs Merkel had to step in.Where Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer had vacillated and negotiated with the rebel politicians, Mrs Merkel ended the crisis with a simple statement, announcing that what they had done was “unforgivable” and must be reversed. It was a brutal demonstration of the difference between the two women, and a death blow to Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer’s personal authority.For an idea of how seriously the “firewall” against any cooperation with the AfD is taken in German politics, consider only that last week’s events were openly compared to the rise of the Nazi party.But if Thuringia ended AKK’s hopes of succeeding Mrs Merkel, her bid started to unravel long before. It began within months after she secured the CDU leadership at the end of 2018.There was her disastrous attempt to woo the party’s conservative wing with an off-colour joke about third gender toilets being for men “who aren't sure whether they can still pee standing up”.When she was called out on that, she doubled down by accusing Germans of being “the most uptight people in the world” — not a good line for some one trying to become chancellor of Germany.But AKK’s biggest mistake in her first months as leader was probably allowing the impression she was on manoeuvres to ease Mrs Merkel out of power early so she could take her place.Mrs Merkel had engineered AKK’s rise within the party specifically to prolong her own time as chancellor. Whatever the truth of what AKK was up to in those early months, by letting reports she wanted Mrs Merkel gone go unchallenged, she appears to have alienated her most important ally.When the CDU performed badly in last year’s European elections, Mrs Merkel repaid her in kind, allowing the word to go around that she had “lost faith” in her former protege.And last September, in a particularly cutting display of power, Mrs Merkel refused to allow AKK and her entourage to share her ministerial flight to the US for the UN climate summit.Without Mrs Merkel’s protection, AKK quickly began to founder. She had an almost uncanny ability for gaffes in the immediate run-up to elections.Just before the European elections she fumbled the CDU’s response to an attack from a prominent Youtube star, allowing it to go unanswered for days.And in the run-up to regional elections in eastern Germany last year she picked a fight with one of the party’s most popular figures in the region.Then there was the confusion over her ministerial role. When she became CDU leader she made great play of the fact she wasn’t taking a cabinet job so she could concentrate on rebuilding the party’s electoral fortunes.But in a U-turn last summer she took on the defence ministry, widely seen as one of the toughest roles in German government. She tried to spin it as a chance to prove herself in high office. But it was no secret in Berlin that she took the job in order to block Jens Spahn, one of her closest rivals, from taking it and using it as a launchpad to challenge her.For a woman already struggling with the party leadership, it was a ludicrous extra burden.Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer will not depart immediately. She said on Monday she would stay on as party leader over the summer while the CDU elects a chancellor candidate to lead it into next year’s election.That race looks set to reopen isions between the Merkellian, moderate wing and the conservatives, and the debate over the party’s future direction.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: analysis irish voters take sinn fein mainstream united ireland
story: The prospect of the nationalist Sinn Fein entering government in Ireland now looks to be very real following last weekend’s election, a move that will make many British voters that recall the Troubles instinctively deeply uncomfortable.But in a world of fragmenting politics that had already ended the longtime duopoly of Ireland’s two mainstream governing parties - Fine Gael and Fianna Fail - it was perhaps only a matter of time before Sinn Fein found a route to power.Still, it seems that no-one - least of all Sinn Fein itself, which didn’t stand in many constituencies - foresaw this happening so quickly, given that the party had polled around 11 per cent in recent European and Presidential elections.But by winning the second-largest number of seats in the Dáil, there is now a very real prospect that a British foreign minister will find themselves sitting across the table from a Sinn Fein Tanaiste whose party is avowedly in favour of reuniting Ireland.This at a time when the British prime minister talks about 'cementing the union' with a £15 billion 'Boris bridge' between Ireland and Scotland - as Northern Ireland’s Unionists complain bitterly that Mr Johnson’s Brexit deal is inexorably sucking the province into Dublin’s economic orbit.If Brexit was not already testing the viability of the deliberate constitutional limbo that underpinned the Good Friday Agreement, then the prospect of Sinn Fein in government surely does so.This does not mean that a ‘border poll’ is anywhere close to being an immediate prospect, since a vote on Irish unity can only be triggered by the British secretary of state “if at any time it appears likely to him” that a majority in Northern Ireland would vote for unification.The best available data, from the Northern Ireland Life and Times Survey which has been surveying opinion since the 1998 peace deal was signed, still only shows around a quarter of Northern Ireland’s population are explicitly pro-unification.Forthcoming election data is expected to show a potential narrow majority among Catholics for Irish Unity, but taking into account the entire population of Northern Ireland, the secretary of state currently has no grounds to call a poll.That is not to diminish the seismic nature of last weekend’s result, and the potential it provides both to change the dynamic between London and Dublin, but also within the Republic of Ireland itself.Although Sinn Fein’s president Mary Lou McDonald clearly won voters over on an anti-austerity ticket, the price of any coalition will be to formalise the unification agenda through a government White Paper that will give official form and content to the idea.If that is the case, then what is now a talking point down the pub or at the bus stop can be given an official, bureaucratic structure and legitimacy that, incrementally, can lay the foundations for the longer term ambitions for unification.We live in constitutionally febrile times. No one can be sure precisely how the Irish ‘frontstop’, with its capacity to hit both business and consumers in the North, will impact the discussion on unification - nor indeed the impact of a Scottish vote for secession.The prospect of Sinn Fein entering government in Dublin is another destabilising ingredient in that volatile constitutional mix.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: british government would do coronavirus spreads
story: As the risk of coronavirus increases, the government is urging local authorities and others to put in place contingency plans to mitigate its potential impact - but what will be needed and when is still uncertain.Plans range from warning religious groups to limit “close contacts”, urging employers to use video conferencing rather than face-to-face meetings, and ensuring that if worst comes to worst, local authorities have capacity to cremate and bury the dead to stop the disease from spreading further.While the situation in the UK remains calm, with only eight cases confirmed so far, government planners are taking precautions.Their response is being driven by the UK Influenza Pandemic Preparedness Strategy 2011, and although this document was prepared for an outbreak of a new strain of flu, it's believed to provide a solid template for the management of coronavirus containment and treatment.In practical terms, if the coronavirus was to take root in Britain as it has in China, these are the sort of measures we might expect to see introduced here: Although schools were kept open during the 2009 swine flu pandemic, case numbers dropped sharply when schools broke up for the holidays, highlighting the role children play in spreading viruses.Imperial College London study published in the Lancet at the time predicted that prolonged closures could reduce the scale of the outbreak by 13-17 per cent and cut the number of swine flu cases by 38-45 per cent at the outbreaks’ peak. It is therefore hoped that closure of schools during the pandemic might break the chains of transmission the researchers said.On Monday it was reported that St Mary's Independent School in Southampton was being closed after a child who had traveled to China developed symptoms of coronavirus.We have taken advice on this situation from Public Health England and the Natural Health Service”, said Claire Charlemagne, the school's headteacher.  But closing schools across England and Wales would not be a decision ministers would make lightly. School closures would cause serious disruption for millions of working parents and lead to a to GDP loss of up to 1 per cent by some estimates. It would also hit NHS capacity hard with as much as 30 per cent of staff having to take time off to look after children just when they are needed most.All businesses should adopt “robust and flexible” contingency plans in case of a pandemic, including appointing a “pandemic coordinator or team” to drive the company response, the Government says.This covers everything from securing supply chains to protecting customers and staff.Initially at least, the overriding focus should be on reducing the spread of infection. This should include providing hand washing facilities and sanitising hand gels, introducing video conferencing in place of face-to face meetings and people working from home where possible.Staggered shifts to reduce overcrowding and restriction on “non-essential” travel, especially to locations known to have a high incidence of the virus, are also recommended, and employers should expect some employees to be absent from personal illness, or bereavement, or transport delays.There are unlikely to be bans on taking public transport but if the the spread of the virus picks up place, expect the government to recommend “non-essential” travel is avoided.Also expect a major information campaign about the importance of good hand and respiratory hygiene when using public transport systems.Trains, buses and especially hub stations are easy places to spread and catch viruses from shared surfaces such as ticket machines, hanging straps, and seats.With most pandemics “hotspots” appear - areas in which the spread of disease races ahead of others. It is possible that local authorities would introduce additional, more draconian, restrictions around such hotspots.  The Government says it is “unlikely to recommend a blanket ban” on religious gatherings or other get-togethers. However, it warns groups - including faith groups - to be aware of the spread of viruses through “close contact” and advises that organisers pay particular attention to hygiene arrangements.Sharing a communal cup is almost certainly a bad idea whether it be in a church or a nightclub. Beware also packed sports stadiums.In the event of a really widespread outbreak, expect nightclubs, restaurants, sports clubs and highstreets to empty voluntarily, just as they have in much of Asia.Estimates for the proportion of people requiring hospitalisation after contracting coronavirus is high, at around 20-30 per cent.  This may change for the better as more is learnt about the virus but it points to a major squeeze on hospital capacity in the UK.Were this to happen, the NHS could start cancelling all but the most urgent primary and secondary care appointments.The government has substantial powers to prevent and control risks to human health from infection or contamination. These powers , which in extremis can seem draconian, stem largely from the recently updated Public Health (Control of Disease) Act 1984.Generally, there is no need to compel people to take action but provided a justice of the peace is satisfied that the situation is serious enough, they can require that you undergo a medical examination, and be kept in isolation.“These figures might be expected to be reduced by the impact of countermeasures, but the effectiveness of such mitigation is not certain”, it adds.Taking account of this, local planners have been set the target of preparing to extend funeral capacity on a “precautionary but reasonably practicable basis”, and aim to cope with a population mortality rate of up to 210,000 to 315,000 additional deaths, possibly over as little as a 15-week period and perhaps half of these over 3 weeks at the height of the outbreak.Local authorities are provided with “a framework”  for managing deaths deaths in the case of a pandemic. Just as has been the case with Ebola in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a priority around the burial will be to ensure it is done promptly and without a ceremony that involves the display and touching of the deceased.Protect yourself and your family by learning more about Global Health Security. title: garden sustainable space how to build tips tricks climate 20 pledges
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.This year, Chris Riotta is growing his own fruit and vegetables – in the middle of New York CityWhether you’re working with a few feet of space in a community vegetable patch, or have 65 acres of luscious foliage on a sprawling estate (looking at you, Oprah Winfrey), the first step to building a sustainable garden is mapping out a vision of your intentions.Each year before planting my own vegetable patch, I draw out an image of the garden I hope to build, indicating where each plant should go based on available sunlight and shading.&nbspI’m currently planning to build the largest garden I’ve ever grown, while working to harvest one-third of my annual vegetable consumption directly from my backyard, as part of my mission for The Independent’s 20&nbspPledges&nbspfor 2020 initiative. While mapping out the garden, I put together a few tips and tricks to help get you started on your own sustainable vegetable patch.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPlan out where to place your&nbspplantsRoot to fruit: How to join the ethical food revolutionI like to plant crops that grow on vines (think: cucumbers and cherry tomatoes) in small groups, as close to a fence as possible so they scale upwards, while giving other plants that will likely grow much larger a separate space off to the side. That way, I can still walk by and tend to the crops growing up the fence, no matter how big the other plants off to the side eventually grow.&nbspThis also works with smaller plots of soil like community garden space: keep clusters of similar plants in the same tight groups, and don’t worry so much about spacing. With some proper TLC, plants usually find their way around each other in the dirt.&nbspSeeds can always begin growing indoors ahead of the season around the time you lay out your soil, which will provide you with plenty of time to start growing your crops in a stable environment. Some farmers will recommend you transport these seeds to your garden based on the location of the moon, but since I don’t have time for all that, I simply give the soil a good rinse of water for a week before transporting or planting anything in my garden.Study your plotBefore stepping into that dirt, it’s important to study your space and gain an understanding of how many hours of sunlight you’re working with and what kind of plants grow well in the region. Most will require about eight hours of sun, but if you’re in a shaded area and can only get six, that should still work, as many plants favour partial shade and only require about four hours of direct sunlight.&nbspGetting a head start on laying out the groundwork for your garden will help it produce sustainable harvests that last throughout the summer months – and then some. You can look up the last frost date in your region here.&nbspI tend to lay out my organic soil exactly where I plant to grow my garden about six weeks before this date.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Back to our roots: Warming winter vegetables recipes Show all 2Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Maximise your spaceIt’s also just as important to consider ways to maximise the space while gardening. Vertical garden walls can be purchased or made easily in DIY projects, allowing plants to grow above each other rather than spread out over a small space.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailLastly, don’t be afraid to plant intensively. Most crops only need a few inches of space for their roots to grow: things like peppers, tomatoes, broccoli and kale can all grow much closer together than most people think. I tend to believe that crops grow better when they’re in close, clustered mixes of similar plants, but that’s just my unprofessional semi-gardening enthusiast opinion.Transplant the seeds to your garden once its warm enough for them to survive in an outdoor climate, but only when the seeds are busting out of their trays or starter pots. The seeds should look vibrant and almost too big for their trays by the time they are brought to the garden for planting.&nbspI tend to believe the first moments catering to a garden and each inidual plant are some of the most important in a life cycle the only way a garden will produce healthy crops is with tender love and care during its birth. title: 20 pledges for 2020 worms food waste wormery climate change
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Julia Platt Leonard is making&nbspher kitchen and her cooking more sustainable in 2020, one meal at a timeI can add to my list of 3:00 a.m. wake-up worries — along with Brexit, the American presidential election, and Harry and Meghan — worm wander. In my 2020 quest for a more sustainable kitchen, I’ve installed a wormery in my back garden. A small move but for me a big one, as I’m still reeling from the time my brother threw a tin of worms at me when I was six years old.&nbspThe worms will feed on kitchen scraps&nbspbits of cabbage, banana peels, and egg shells (no oil, no dairy please) that my 2019.0 version would have tossed into the garbage. They’ll reside in a multi-level des res and churn my waste into compost. But as I feverishly read the instructions, I learn that during the first 24-hours they might ‘wander’ and head for the great outdoors. &nbspI call Ronnie, co-owner of Wormcity Wormery, who calms me down. Yes, there is a potential for wander but adding a handful of our own back garden soil helps ‘welcome’ the worms to their new home. No, it’s not a problem that I’m going away for a week — they need time to get settled and overfeeding is a no-no anyway. I hang up feeling like I’ve had a session with my own worm therapist.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesWhy I’m promising to end all my food wasteIf you’ve got any back garden space, then a wormery is an easy way to reduce your kitchen carbon footprint. You can find them online and at garden shops and it’s an easy-to-assemble box system (more mouths  more food waste  more levels). I chose Wormcity because — aside from the fact that Ronnie doesn’t mind answering my inane questions — their wormeries are made from recycled plastic in England, so helpfully reducing travel miles.&nbspMy composting worms should live for around two to three years. They’re prolific, doubling their numbers every three to four months. Even better, they’re hungry — eating up to half their body weight in food every day. That’s a lot of carrot peelings. It will take around four months for my worms to turn a tray of food scraps into compost but when they do, it will be so nutrient rich (about ten thousand times the bacteria and microbes of normal compost) that I’ll only need a small amount to use as a top dressing.&nbspOf course, recycling is only part of the sustainability push. Many argue that the first rule, the mantra, if you will,&nbspis to reduce. If we reduce the amount we buy in the first place, then we won’t need to recycle so much. We’ll also save money. The United States Department of Agriculture estimates that an average American family of four loses $1,500 a year on uneaten food. Like many, I’ve become a BOGO junkie — buying two bottles of juice when I can only drink one at a time or splashing out on three packets of sweet potato falafel for the price of two, when I know that I’ll be pushed to finish the second, let alone the third, by the time I reach the use-by date. Every time I buy food, the clock is ticking. It might be ticking loudly, like when I buy a packet of chicken thighs, but even if I’m buying something shelf stable like rice or pasta, it’s still ticking.After my January fridge detox, I realised that the more stuff I’ve got in my fridge, the harder it is to find anything. And sadly when I do, it might be too late. During my trawl, I discovered two open bottles of fish sauce, which by anyone’s standards is one too many. I know exactly what happened — I was in a rush, opened up the fridge, did a quick look, didn’t (couldn’t) see any so opened another bottle. Shame on me.&nbspNow I’m shopping with intention, as I call it. Considering my purchases more carefully and using up what I’ve got before I go crazy buying more. I rescued some Jurassic-era carrots from the veg bin but rather than throw them out, I peeled them, gave them a quick turn in salted boiling water and a refresh in cold water. The wrinkled romano pepper that looked like something out of an ad for sunscreen was sliced, seeded, roasted and then blitzed with nuts, lemon zest, olive oil, garlic and some almost-chuckable herbs. I tossed the carrots in my ersatz romesco sauce and they were delicious.&nbspI discovered no less than three containers of parmesan cheese in the dark recesses of my fridge. I combined them so they’re easier to locate and will use the wedge for grating and toss the nobbly rinds into my next batch of minestrone for an umami hit. Containers heading to the freezer are labelled now, with the exception of a mystery one I missed, which I’ve decided is either chilli con carne or bolognaise. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Alli apologised for the Snapchat post in a video on the Chinese social media platform Weibo on SundayThe Football Association has written to Tottenham midfielder Dele Alli to seek his observations about a social media post in which he appeared to joke about the coronavirus.The England player, 23, has been contacted concerning a Snapchat video he posted on Saturday. In it, he joked about the virus outbreak and appeared to mock an Asian man. The coronavirus has so far claimed the lives of over 900 people in mainland China, according to official figures.Alli apologised for the Snapchat post in a video on the Chinese social media platform Weibo on Sunday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Hi guys, it’s Dele I just wanted to apologise on my behalf for the video I posted on Snapchat yesterday,” he said. “It wasn’t funny and I realised that immediately and took it down. I let myself down and the club.“I don’t want you to have that impression of me because it wasn’t funny and I realised that straight away and took it down. It isn’t something that should be joked about. I’m sending all my love and all my thoughts and prayers to everyone in China.”The FA’s guidelines around media comments and social media posts remind participants that it will consider charges under Rule E3 if it is felt that someone has acted in an improper manner or brings the game into disrepute.It would be considered an aggravated breach if a comment or social media post, whether explicitly or implicitly, makes reference to ethnic origin, colour, race, nationality, religion or belief, gender, gender reassignment, sexual orientation or disability.The latest football headlines direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Data could be transmitted a thousand times faster than current internet cables after a major breakthrough, scientists have said.The new research uses&nbspterahertz quantum cascade lasers that could send data around the world at speeds unimaginable using current technology.The lasers could be used to vastly speed up data communications, according to the researchers behind the study, which is published today in the journal&nbspNature Communications.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe study saw researchers make a breakthrough in the control of&nbspterahertz quantum cascade lasers, which they say could be used to transmit data at a speed of 100 gigabits. Current – very fast – ethernet connections work at 100 megabits a second, a thousand times less quick.The specific kind of lasers are different because they send out light in the terahertz&nbsprange of the electromagnetic spectrum, which is largely used to analyse chemicals. But by turning them to use to send data, they could provide much faster connections for research facilities, hospitals, satellite communications or any other situations where very fast network connections are required.Created with Sketch.Gadget and tech news: In pictures Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.125 Gun-toting humanoid robot sent into spaceRussia has launched a humanoid robot into space on a rocket bound for the International Space Station (ISS). times every second. That requires precise control, and engineers have so far been unable to do it.This is life under the longest internet shutdown in historyNow researchers think they have found a way of controlling that very fast modulation, using sound and light.This is exciting research,&nbspsaid John Cunningham, Professor of Nanoelectronics at Leeds. At the moment, the system for modulating a quantum cascade laser is electrically driven - but that system has limitations.Ironically, the same electronics that delivers the modulation usually puts a brake on the speed of the modulation. The mechanism we are developing relies instead on acoustic waves.When an electron passes through the optical part of the laser, it travels through a host of quantum wells that throw out a pulse of light energy. An electron can emit a number of those photons, and that is controlled – using soundwaves&nbspto vibrate those quantum wells – in the new experiment.Essentially, what we did was use the acoustic wave to shake the intricate electronic states inside the quantum cascade laser, said&nbspTony Kent, Professor of Physics at Nottingham. We could then see that its&nbspterahertz&nbsplight output was being altered by the acoustic wave.The research is not perfect, and more control is still needed before the lasers could be used reliably to transmit data. But with further work they could lead to major breakthroughs in transmitting data.We did not reach a situation where we could stop and start the flow completely, but we were able to control the light output by a few percent, which is a great start, said Professor Cunningham.We believe that with further refinement, we will be able to develop a new mechanism for complete control of the photon emissions from the laser, and perhaps even integrate structures generating sound with the terahertz laser, so that no external sound source is needed.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The broadcaster's flagship channel struggles&nbspamid destructive weather: 'Causing us some problems'BBC One went off-air for more than seven minutes on Sunday morning due to interference by Storm Ciara.&nbspThe BBC's flagship channel, which at the time was broadcasting Nicky Campbell's&nbspThe Big Questions, began to glitch at 11.02am before dropping off completely a minute later.&nbspThis is BBC One, I'm sorry but due to technical problems we've lost contact with The Big Questions studio in Salford, an announcer said shortly afterwards.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesInstead of moving images, the broadcast played&nbspsmooth jazz music alongside a message which read: We are sorry for the break in this programme and are trying to correct the fault.She later added: It seems that the stormy conditions up in Salford are causing us some problems. We are working as hard as we can against the weather to get back to Big Questions and Nicky in Salford as quickly&nbspas we can.At 11.08am, the announcer said the channel had solved the issue and thanked&nbspviewers for bearing with us, resulting in&nbspa failed attempt to return the broadcast to TV screens.Unfortunately we're not able to go back to Big Questions in Salford,&nbspbut please do bear with us one second, while we figure out what we're gonna do this morning, she then apologised.It was not until 11.10am that footage returned as normal.&nbspThe unusual interruption came amid travel chaos inflicted by Ciara, which is the worst storm to strike&nbspBritain in seven years.&nbspTrains, flights and ferries have been cancelled and severe weather warnings issued as&nbspCiara was forecast to pummel the UK with winds of up to 80mph.Created with Sketch. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Sharon Choi&nbspwas one of the highlights of Sunday’s Oscar ceremonySharon Choi, the&nbspKorean-American filmmaker who charmed audiences&nbspby translating&nbspParasite&nbspdirector Bong Joon Ho’s&nbspspeeches during Sunday’s Oscar’s ceremony, has written a film.“Actually, she’s writing some feature-length script – I’m so curious&nbspabout it.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesChoi, 25, was next to Bong throughout the evening, as he collected awards for Best Director, Best International Film and Best Original Screenplay.The Wrap&nbspreporter Steve Pond reported on Twitter that&nbspChoi said: “she wants to start making a movie ... about awards season.”&nbspCreated with Sketch.Oscars 2020 in pictures Show all 65Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Bong Joon Ho, right, reacts as he is presented with the award for best picture for Parasite from presenter Jane Fonda at the Oscars on Sunday, Feb. 9, 2020, at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mysterious pattern could be an important clue to the origin of mysterious blastsA mysterious radio signal coming from deep in space appears to be repeating in a pattern, say scientists.The powerful blast is coming from somewhere unknown and extragalactic, and is perhaps the most unusual fast radio burst ever detected by scientists.Researchers have already spotted a number of the fast radio bursts originating from deep in space. They have even seen that limited numbers of them appear to repeat.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut the new breakthrough, spotted by scientists using a telescope in Canada and described in an early paper published online, is the first time that researchers have seen the blasts appearing in a regular, predictable pattern.Astronomers have no confirmed explanation for the FRBs, with the only certain fact about their origin that they must be coming from somewhere very extreme and unusual. Proposed explanations have included everything from alien civilisations sending us messages to a star falling into a black hole, but the fact that the messages are repeating have led some scientists to lead out such cataclysmic causes.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It has since been suggested that they may instead be formed by flowing sand NasaJPLUniversity of ArizonaMorning Aurora: Nasa astronaut Scott Kelly captured this photograph of the green lights of the aurora from the International Space Station in October 2015The FRBs are in a 16-day cycle that sees them appear and then go dark, before doing the same all over again. Over the course of the cycle, the bursts will appear intensely for a four day flurry that sees a signal come every hour or more, and then it will go quiet for 12 days.That pattern is an important clue to the nature of this object, the researchers write in the new paper.Are aliens sending us messages from light years away?It appears to be coming from the edge of a massive spiral galaxy, about 500 million light years away, the researchers say. But there are few other clues about where it could be coming from or the processes that may have given rise to it.The fact that it is repeating over a predictable period could suggest that it is coming from a binary system, since other objects in space that demonstrate similar characteristics tend to be binary systems, too. The object could be being swung around by a star or black hole, and the periodic blasts could be an indication that the object is facing us during those times, the researchers say.It could also be possible that winds or tidal disruptions from the black hole block the signal during the periods it is silent, they note.The repeating signals were spotted by the&nbspCanadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment, which spends time looking for more FRBs in an attempt to find their origin. It should spend more time looking at the source of the current bursts – known as&nbspFRB 180916.J0158+65 – in an attempt to learn more about it, the researchers conclude in their paper, which is for now published on the website ArXiv before being peer reviewed and published in a journal.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Apple needs to fix those keyboards, he said. They are impossible to write on. They've gotten worse.It makes me want to go back to PCs. the closed Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market“I would like to thank the NHS for their help and care – whilst I have fully recovered, my thoughts are with others who have contracted coronavirus,” Mr Walsh said in a statement from quarantine in London’s St Thomas’ Hospital on Tuesday.“As soon as I knew I had been exposed to a confirmed case of coronavirus I contacted my GP, NHS 111 and Public Health England.“I was advised to attend an isolated room at hospital, despite showing no symptoms, and subsequently self-isolated at home as instructed.“When the diagnosis was confirmed I was sent to an isolation unit in hospital, where I remain, and, as a precaution, my family was also asked to isolate themselves.“I also thank friends, family and colleagues for their support during recent weeks and I ask the media to respect our privacy.Of four Britons who tested positive for the virus on Monday, two were healthcare workers. Brighton’s County Oak medical centre was closed amid reports of workers wearing protective suits cleaning the surgery.Public Health England confirmed the newly announced cases were “closely linked” as efforts were made to trace other people who may have been exposed to the virus.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Singaporean authorities are said to be investigating the business meeting, attended by Mr Walsh with his company Servomex, alongside more than 90 other foreign nationals.&nbspServomex said “a limited number of its employees in different countries have been diagnosed with the coronavirus and are now being treated”.Officials hunt for patients of coronavirus-infected healthcare workersTrump cautioned for insisting ‘coronavirus will be gone by April’Should I pick up my family from the airport amid coronavirus outbreak?The Grand Hyatt Singapore, a five-star hotel with 677 guest rooms, said Singapore’s Ministry of Health informed it that three people who attended the conference experienced symptoms after returning to their home countries of Malaysia and South Korea and have now been diagnosed with the virus.The hotel said 94 foreigners stayed at the Grand Hyatt at the same time as the Servomex conference, including people from Wuhan, the Chinese city at the epicenter of the story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Dismissal comes hours after Chancellor asked for a 'durable' system, in blow to Boris JohnsonThe EU's chief negotiator has immediately rejected&nbspa plea by Sajid Javid to protect the City's access to EU financial markets after Brexit.The Chancellor had called for a “reliable equivalence process” for financial services rules on which “a durable relationship” can be built with the EU.But just hours after the proposal was published Brussels' chief negotiator Michel Barnier&nbspdealt a blow to Boris Johnson's negotiating strategy.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesI would like to take this opportunity to make it clear to certain people in the United Kingdom bearing authority that they should not kid themselves about this - there will not be general, open-ended, ongoing equivalence in financial services, he said.Mr Barnier added that the EU would retain a free hand to take our own decisions and would simply not negotiate with the UK on this point.The Chancellor had said the Government wanted to conclude a full range of equivalence assessments by June 2020 - allowing the UK and EU to respect each other's rules.EU insists UK must keep regulations if it wants trade dealUK Brexit timetable not long enough for full trade deal, says Barnier‘Difficult to see’ how Brexit deal can be reached, EU’s Barnier saysBut he also said the UK would keep the freedom to erge and regulate in a different way from the rules set in Brussels.Each side will only grant equivalence if it believes the other's regulations are compatible, he wrote in the City AM newspaper.But compatible does not mean identical, and both the UK and the EU have at different times recognised the importance of focusing on regulatory outcomes.We will no longer be rule-takers, but we remain committed to the highest international standards of financial regulation and to shaping global rule-making.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailThe question at stake is whether EU authorities would call the shots on whether UK firms were complying with EU regulations to trade on the continent.&nbspI would like to take this opportunity to make it clear to certain people in the United Kingdom bearing authority that they should not kid themselvesIf that were the case, the UK would be a less attractive location to base a financial institution in because it could be frozen out of EU markets at the whim of European regulators.Under a more durable agreement as suggested by Mr Javid, market access would be backed at treaty level and it would be harder to freeze out UK firms. If this were the case, banks and other financial institutions could base themselves in the UK knowing they might not be frozen out by EU regulators one day to the next.As a result of Britain's departure from the EU, City firms will lose their automatic passporting rights to keep doing business on the continent.Created with Sketch.Brexit celebrations in Parliament Square Show all 37Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Pro-Brexit supporters celebrating in Parliament Square, after the UK left the European Union on 31 January. People are not daft.”The internal report was widely ridiculed for excusing Mr Corbyn and claiming the overwhelming focus on Brexit played the “decisive role” in handing Boris Johnson victory.Created with Sketch.Who could replace Corbyn as Labour leader? Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The former director of public prosecutions undoubtedly has announced that he is standing for the leadership. He is highly-regarded by both left-wingers and centrists in the party. As Labour’s shadow Brexit secretary, he played a key role in the party’s eventual backing of a second referendum. A key ally of the current left-wing leadership of the party, the Salford &amp Eccles MP is viewed in some quarters as the natural successor to Mr Corbyn and describes herself as a “proud socialist”. Highly regarded by the shadow chancellor, John McDonnell. She won also won plaudits for her performance filling in for Corbyn both at prime minister’s questions and during the general election debates.Corbyn’s constituency neighbour and friend, Emily Thornberry, has been critical of the party’s Brexit stance, but has remained loyal to the leadership and has represented the Labour Party on various overseas visits. Shadow education secretary Angela Rayner has joined the contest for deputy leadership of the party. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.A state the Democrats have held since the 1970s is now slipping away — and one candidate says she can save itWith Joe Biden’s campaign apparently collapsing and Elizabeth Warren's showing signs of decline, the political narrative in New Hampshire over the last week began to centre on the rivalry between frontrunners Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigeig. But in the primary’s last few days, someone else broke into the upper tier.Arise, Amy Klobuchar, a longtime senator who just happens to hail from one of the most important states on the Democrats’ target list: Minnesota.For all the talk about the so-called “blue wall” states that Hillary Clinton lost in 2016, namely Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin, Klobuchar’s home state is one of several traditionally safe Democratic states that slipped perilously close to turning red.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTop (or bottom) of that list is New Hampshire, which Clinton won by only 0.37 points — but Minnesota is second. Clinton defeated Trump there by just 44,765 votes, or 1.52 points. As the Democrats try and build an electoral college majority once again, that’s close enough to be deeply concerning.Created with Sketch.Democratic candidates compete on the campaign trail: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A man holds up a sign criticising billionaires in the presidential race in front of Michael Bloomberg in Compton, Califronia. From left to right: Billionaire-philanthropist Tom Steyer, Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, former vice president Joe Biden, Vermont senator Bernie Sanders, mayor of South Bend, Indiana, Pete Buttigieg and Minnesota senator Amy KlobucharBut thanks to Clinton’s near miss, its moment in the sun has come. The Democrats need to hold on to every state they can, and that’s before they pick up several others. And so, to Klobuchar.Since the start of her campaign, she has consistently argued that winning three consecutive&nbspsenate elections for her Minnesota seat proves she can hold on to or win back Midwestern swing states. That record does rather set her apart from the rest of the Democratic top tier:&nbspPete Buttigeig has only won mayoral elections in a small city, in a state the Democrats look highly unlikely to win this year, while Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders hail from Democratic home turf in Massachusetts and Vermont.&nbspAnd while much has been made of Joe Biden’s roots in Pennsylvania, his decades-long career was in tiny and ultra-safe Delaware, and his floundering campaign may not even get him through the looming South Carolina primary.Klobuchar’s record therefore makes her uniquely appealing, and she seems well-placed to leverage it today. Political scientist and US politics expert Brian Klaas said: “Klobuchar is popular across the state,” boasting “approval ratings that reflect her ability to win over swing voters but also win over some Republicans”.On the face of it, this was borne out by her re-election as senator in 2018, when she won 57 of Minnesota’s 87 counties and bested her Republican challenger by 24 points. But in fact, her performance somewhat ebbed even in a year where the Democrats did well nationwide — and more concerning still, her vote apparently shifted away from “Trump country” towards the state’s urban centres.For 2020 Democrats, Granite State is boom or bustHow much does winning the New Hampshire primary actually matter?There’s only one Democrat who can oust TrumpAccording to Klaas, this may not be enough in an election with Trump on the ballot. “For a Democrat to win in Minnesota, they need to do well statewide. They need to run up a substantial margin in the Twin Cities — the neighbouring cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul that straddle the Mississippi — but they can’t win just with cities.“They need to have support in the suburbs, which are often swing districts but broke for the Democrats in the 2018 midterms. And rural Minnesota is largely Trump territory these days, but soybean farmers in the south are being hit badly by Trump’s trade war, and many iron ore miners in the northeast Iron Range who voted for Trump come from union households that have voted for Democrats for generations.”So can Klobuchar do it? Even beyond the so-called “home state advantage”, which has been the subject of decades of academic research, she has several advantages over Hillary Clinton: she isn’t trying to win her party a third consecutive term, she has relatively little baggage of her own, and she’s running against a controversial Republican incumbent.But first, she has to win the nomination. And on that front, she has a ways to go. Heading into the New Hampshire primary, an Ipsos poll found that more than a third of respondents either don’t have an opinion about her or hadn’t heard of her at all. If she wants to lead the Democrats into Minnesota and elsewhere this November, she’ll have to raise her profile — and soon.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Latest political turmoil may have been straw that broke camel’s backThe leader of Germany’s main governing party – widely seen as Angela Merkel’s anointed successor – has said she will step aside and not stand to become chancellor.Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer took over as head of the centre-right CDU party in December 2018, but admitted that her party had faced a “difficult year” with her in charge.The decision came after a week of political turmoil in Germany that raised questions about her ability to command authority in Germany’s largest political party.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesLocal CDU politicians in the state of Thuringia had voted alongside the far-right AfD party to install a joint candidate as regional governor – defying Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer and causing a national political scandal.&nbspCooperation with the far right is a major taboo in Germany, with other&nbspparties expected to maintain “cordon sanitaire” around them.Brexit is a ‘wake-up call’ for Europe, says Angela MerkelThe fight to succeed Angela Merkel could change the course of EuropeWhile the row did not directly drag in Ms&nbspKramp-Karrenbauer, it may have been the straw that broke the camel’s back in illustrating her weak grip on the party.“I will not run for chancellor,” the 57-year-old told a press conference in Berlin, adding that she had made her decision “with the intention of strengthening the CDU”.“In my view, this has no impact on the stability of the grand coalition,” she said, suggesting that the federal coalition government between her party and the centre-left SPD would continue.The CDU leader, who is also known in Germany as “AKK”, took over the top party post while Ms Merkel remained Germany’s chancellor. She made the surprise announcement after a meeting of members.&nbspMs Merkel herself told reporters in Berlin: “I acknowledged this decision today with the greatest amount of respect, but I want to say that I regret it.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: bbc no longer loved broadcaster
story: If you are a lavishly overpaid BBC presenter or senior manager with your snout stuffed deep into the corporation’s publicly-funded trough, then three quid is nothing — around the price of a semi-skimmed latte made with almond milk from that delightful little café outside Broadcasting House.But coming when it did — immediately after the BBC’s wretchedly biased coverage of the moment we left the European Union — hiking the archaic telly tax felt grotesquely provocative.And I realised that the BBC’s big problem today is that it is unloved. The young folk born this century, like my -year-old daughter, do not watch it. The BBC means nothing to Generation YouTube.And the millions of us who grew up with the Beeb no longer recognise it as the benign Auntie that gave us Doctor Who, Top Of The Pops, Le On Earth, Fawlty Towers, The Likely Lads and David Dimbleby staying up all night at the General Election.That old beloved BBC — endlessly entertaining, scrupulously fair — is dead now. The BBC’s coverage of the night we left the European Union was nothing less than shameful.Here was a moment of truly historical signicance, the kind of national event that the BBC was born to cover. And it was dished up like a dull night at the Eurovision Song Contest.Down in Parliament Square, awash with Union Jacks and peaceful, happy patriots, BBC reporter Geeta Guru-Murthy blurted: “It’s a very white crowd mostly” — to the bewilderment of the many black and Asian people who were there to celebrate.But, of course, the BBC continues to peddle the filthy little lie that Brexit has its roots in the racism of the bigoted British people.Meanwhile, Sophie Raworth sat primly in a BBC studio made up to look like the EU flag. The studio never turned red, white and blue. There was no sense that the largest vote for anything in British history was being honoured. Why must we pay £billion a year for this one-sided garbage My colleague Ally Ross has pointed out that BBC “comedy” shows like Have I Got News For You, Frankie Boyle’s New World Order and The Mash Report have all been larded with anti-Brexit orthodoxy for years. Now the predictably loony Remainer-speak even seeps into the poison the BBC drips into our children.On the day we left the EU, the BBC released a CBBC Horrible Histories special mocking British stupidity.Queen Victoria was accused of callously sweetening her tea with sugar harvested by slaves — even though slavery was abolished four years before Victoria came to the throne.Historian Andrew Roberts described the mocking film as “a stream of bigoted hatred directed at this country”. They truly don’t get it in Broadcasting House. Millions of licence fee payers are deeply offended by the BBC’s relentlessly anti-British, anti-Brexit sentiment.It is why we fell out of love with the BBC. There is talk about decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee, or making payment optional. But the BBC no longer represents the entire nation. It peddles the prejudices of the disappointed elite who run it.The BBC does not speak for the British people. It doesn’t even seem to like us very much. So why should we pay anything at all for this crap AFTER being overlooked at the Oscars for her sensational performance in Hustlers, the half-time show at the Super Bowl felt like the revenge of Jenner Lopez.But Hustlers is my favourite film of the past  months. Lopez deserved an Oscar for her role.And whoever wins Best Actress at the Oscars tonight, I bet they can’t slide down a pole like her.MICHELLE OBAMA always said: “When they go low, we go high.”Meaning that when the Republican opponents of President Obama struck a low blow the Obamas had a strict policy of keeping their cool, their dignity and the moral high ground.The most senior Democratic politician in America just failed to take Michelle Obama’s advice. At his State of the Union address, President Trump petulantly refused to shake the hand of NancyPelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives. Pelosi should have shrugged off Trump’s rudeness and perhaps laughed in Donald’s orange face.Instead, clearly boiling with rage, Nancy ripped a copy of Trump’s speech to pieces. As the speech was full of optimistic stuff about making America a fairer, more prosperous place, the only person Pelosi humiliated was herself.The Democrats are starting to make Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party look like an effective opposition.THE classic James Bond films – Dr No, From Russia With Love, Goldfinger – were all less than two hours long.But in the modern fashion for over-long movies – The Irishman clocks in at three hours and  minutes – the next Bond film, No Time To Die, will be the longest ever at almost three hours.Let’s hope that means plenty of Ana de Armas, , as Bond girl Paloma. And not too much of Daniel Craig, , moaning about ’s dodgy knees.Teenage girls are messier than teenage boys. But teenage boys are, in my experience, more likely to leave takeaway pizza under the bed for six months for the mice to nibble.And when vermin move in, you really long for your little darling to move out.SUCKING up to the millionaire snowflakes in the audience, Prince William complained about the lack of ersity at the Baftas.I don’t believe it. This year a black actor, Micheal Ward, won the Rising Star Bafta for gang film Blue Story. Six years ago,  Years A Slave won Best Picture, competing with epic Hollywood fare like Gravity.If the film or performance is good enough, then the Baftas is colour blind.The real lack of ersity is among British actors. These days most of them went to Eton with Prince William. Now that’s what I call a lack of ersity.A SURVEY reveals that  per cent of Canadians are against paying the £million to-£million-a-year security bill for Harry and Meghan’s new le.Wherever they lay their hats, from Toronto to Tinsel Town, there is only one sucker who will ever pay for Harry and Meghan’s security. The poor old British taxpayer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: meghan markle faking love prince harry germaine greer
story: The controversial feminist told Australian broadcaster  Minutes she was sceptical of just how authentic the Duchess had been in her marriage, with the outcome likely to be disastrous.The -year-old said: “All I can think is shed better be in love.”“If shes been faking it all this time, oh boy, what misery. How many orgasms will it take  How many fake groans will get her through this ”Greer’s comments come after Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s decision to step back from the Royal Family last month.Since quitting their roles as senior royals, it has been reported that Megan is looking for an agent in a possibleto showbiz, with Harry even caught on camera pitching his we as a voice over artist to Disney CEO Bob Iger.Many believe their self-imposed abdication was a ploy driven by the “fame-hungry” former Suits star in a bid toto Hollywood.Long-time royal critic Germaine Greer suggests there were warning signs of ‘Megxit’ from the outset.Greer told  Minutes the Duchess’ potential to manipulate her husband in order to climb the “celebrity” ladder was evident in their extravagant £ million wedding, which was “full of showbiz.”She said: “The marriage was terrible too, because it was full of showbiz personalities, asMegan lived in a completely articial world.”The whole point about showbiz - its not real, and it wont sustain you.”Greer explained she wasnt at all surprised when the couple announced their plans to step back from Royal duties just  days after walking down the aisle.Just two years ago, she told  Minutes: Shell bolt. title: sinn fein irish election britain
story: For anyone under  who does not realise the signicance, Sinn Fein was for decades the unashamed political wing of the Provisional IRA as it carried out a murderous spree in Northern Ireland and on mainland Britain.Under former president Gerry Adams, it always denied sharing a leadership, but few were convinced these two organisations were not effectively one and the same.As former IRA volunteer and Sinn Fein PR chief Danny Morrison memorably put it, the strategy for Irish Republicans was to seize power, “With a ballot paper in this hand and an Armalite in the other.”Sothey do manage to gain power — far from guaranteed with Ireland’s complex electoral system — what will it mean for Britain Sinn Fein continues to push for Irish unication. But providing it does so through democratic means only, that should not upset many people.After all, it is up to the people of Northern Ireland, through a referendum, to decide whether they want to remain part of the UK or to join Ireland.Sinn Fein can, however, be relied upon to be even more hostile than Leo Varadkar — up until now Ireland’s leader — towards Britain in trade negotiations with the EU.If the party can score some kind of victory by opposing UK proposals, it will do so, making it more likely we will have no trade deal by December .Sinn Fein has used Brexit to its advantage, trying to drive a wedge between Britain and those in Northern Ireland who traditionally want to stay part of the Union.By negotiating a deal which puts some kind of border down the Irish Sea, Boris Johnson’s government has helped Sinn Fein’s cause. Former Irish leader Bertie Aern claimed yesterday that a referendum on a united Ireland will now come before the end of the decade.“I think a border poll is inevitable,” he said. “I think it’s probably five years off at least but the Sinn Fein position is it should be held within five years.”It is easy to see a scenario in which Northern Ireland votes to leave the UK and join Ireland, followed by a Scottish vote for independence.I am not sure where that would leave Boris’s plans for a Belfast to Stranraer bridge, which of course would have been paid for mostly by English taxpayers.All this said, however, there is little to suggest that those who voted for Sinn Fein on Sunday were motivated by concerns over Brexit or by a desire for a united Ireland.Strip away its dubious past and Sinn Fein is now a party of the Corbynite Left — it wants far greater social programmes, all funded by the wealthy.This could have serious consequences in a country whose economic success is founded on low taxes, especially company taxes. Ireland’s corporation tax rate is just . per cent, compared with  per cent in the UK. That has helped it become a magnet for investment.In terms of GDP per head, Ireland was poorer than the UK  years ago, but now it is signicantly richer.But whatSinn Fein was able to do what Jeremy Corbyn promised to do and soak the rich We might no longer have a Celtic Tiger on our doorstep, but a Celtic Sloth. The likes of Amazon and Google, which have established big presences in Ireland for tax purposes, might want to sht operations to Britain instead.Leo Varadkar had hoped he would be rewarded at the ballot box for holding a tough line in Brexit negotiations, but Ireland’s housing crisis seems to have been a far stronger concern.Ireland, even more so than Britain, has suffered from property booms and busts over the past two decades.Many young people have been priced out of the housing market and are struggling to even rent. Sinn Fein did well because it promised a three-year rent freeze and , new homes.These pledges helped the party — which has dominated Republican politics in Northern Ireland — come out of the margins south of the border and break the duopoly of the two main partiesIt won . per cent of the vote, while Fianna Fail, a socially conservative party, won  per cent, and Fine Gael, the more economically and socially liberal party of Leo Varadkar, won just  per cent.If Ireland had Britain’s first-past-the-post system, it would have been a landslide — Sinn Fein topped the poll in  of the country’s  constituencies.But given Ireland’s system of multi-member constituencies, it is far from guaranteed that Sinn Fein will even be in government at all.Before the election, Fianna Fail and Fine Gael both said they would not go into government with Sinn Fein. They could go into coalition with each other.In fact, Fianna Fail was already propping up Fine Gael in a confidence and supply arrangement. But with Sinn Fein topping the poll, this might prove a more dficult position to hold.Sinn Fein says it is exploring trying to put together a government without either of the main parties.But despite winning the biggest share of the vote, Ireland’s political establishment may yet succeed in keeping it out of power — and away from messing up the Irish economy. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu style handouts farmers 25 years
story: The Government has guaranteed farmers will continue receiving payments that they currently receive from the EU’s hated Common Agricultural Policy for at least the next five years.But there is a “live discussion” between the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairsand the Department for International Tradeover how long the subsidies should continue for.Remarkably, some in Defra want the payments gradually phased out over  years.But DIT wants the handouts to end within five years and have warned any longer could hinder Britain’s ability to strike new trade deals with the like of the US, Australia and New Zealand.American officials are very keen to put agriculture products at the centre of a trade deal but have warned thatBritish farmers are backed by huge state subsidies for the next two decades then it would limit US UK trade.One Whitehall official accused Defra of “bowing to demands” of the National Farmers Union, who are lobbying for as much protection for farmers as possible.Another added: If they get their way then we can kiss goodbye to signing a bumper trade deal with the US.The EU’s hated Common Agricultural Policycurrently hands a whopping £.billion a year to farmers based on the amount of land they own rather than what they do to it.The stand-off between the two departments has left the issue outstanding despite the Agriculture Bill currently going through Parliament.The draft law proposes that a transition period for farmer handouts lasts for seven years but one official in Defra said: “It’s not signed, sealed and delivered yet”.They also said it was subject to wranglings between ious departments.The payments will gradually be replaced by a system that hands landowners grants for land management projects that improve the environment such as tree-planting and schemes that boost air and water quality.Examples would include anti-flooding schemes that allows overflowing rivers to run through their fields so they avoid towns and villages or farmers who reduce fertilisers that cause pollution.A Whitehall official said: “We want to make sure we secure the best trade deals as a whole and that includes the agriculture industry.“There is a live discussion going on over theof time payments last for. Defra is looking much more favourably on  years.“With negotiations with the US fast-approaching, this is a decision that needs to be made.”A government spokesperson said: “Our landmark Agriculture Bill will reform our agriculture policy, putting the interests of farmers and land managers, the environment and taxpayers at its core as we free ourselves from the EU’s bureaucratic Common Agricultural Policy.“As part of this, we’ve been clear that farmers will have a seven-year agricultural transition period to plan ahead and adjust to these changes.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house of lords insults democracy
story: The unelected chamber was already on thin ice before peers spent three years shamefully trying to overturn Brexit while pocketing £ a day tax-free.And you might think that, with their public standing now shredded, they would have the decency to freeze that rate. Especially with inflation at only . per cent. But no.They’ve voted themselves an inflation-busting . per cent instead — so they’ll now get £ just for showing up.A few Lords and Ladies have experience and ability, we admit. The rest shuffle in for the warmth and the cash.The truth is the House of Lords is an antiquated insult to our democracy, a dumping ground for political failures and discredited cronies, where almost no one is too odious . . . though it still draws the line at Bercow, obviously.A courageous Government with a big majority would take it on and reinvent it as a mainly elected second chamber — with a small handful of unelected peers chosen for specic expertise.How about it, Boris THE decision on whether to proceed with the HS high-speed rail project was bound to upset plenty of people whichever way it went.So perhaps it is no surprise that Boris Johnson has tried to appease both its supporters and opponents by pressing ahead with the bulk of the £billion project, while putting two of its northern spurs on pause.But the PM is shrewd enough to realise that the places losing out — Crewe to Manchester and the West Midlands to Leeds — are the very areas that he must keep on sidehis -seat majority is not to be a one-off.Boris’s alternative transport plans for them, with improved bus and cycle links just a start, must not let them down.Otherwise the snub could see Labour rebuild its “red wall” of voters as quickly as he demolished it.THE Cabinet reshuffle this week must be bold. It will define Boris’s premiership.There are obviously talented contenders for bigger jobs: among them Michael Gove, Rishi Sunak and Victoria Atkins.But this is not the moment for the PM to reward other time-servers whose turn has come. Boris must not overlook fresh faces from the  and  intakes and, while it is probably too early for December’s newcomers, why not,they have the talent This Government already has a place in history simply by forcing Brexit through on January .With dynamic, imaginative, bright and brave ministers it can be truly radical too. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Businessman Steve Walsh, , is feared to have infected at least  people across Europe and the UK over the past two weeks.The dad-of-two, from Hove, East Sussex, is now in quarantine in a London hospital after becoming infected at a Singapore conference last month.It comes as two primary schools told kids to stay at home over fears teachers may have caught coronavirus, and a second GP surgery was put on lockdown.Speaking from hospital, Mr Walsh said in a statement: I would like to thank the NHS for their help and care – whilst I have fully recovered, my thoughts are with others who have contracted coronavirus.As soon as I knew I had been exposed to a confirmed case of coronavirus I contacted my GP, NHS  and Public Health England.I was advised to attend an isolated room at hospital, despite showing no symptoms, and subsequently self-isolated at home as instructed.Do you know anyone infected with coronavirus  Contact joe.duggan@news or call   When the diagnosis was confirmed I was Scout Movement is suffering from coronavirus.He contracted the virus while out of the UK.This volunteer has not been to any Scout meetings since histo the UK.“We wish him well and hope he recovers soon.”More than , people have died as the deadly virus tears through China.There have been more than , confirmed cases across the world.The total number of people infected in the UK has doubled in  hours to eight with Brighton now at the heart of Britains spiralling coronavirus crisis.Today, pupils at Cottesmore St Marys Catholic Primary School were told to stay at home after it was revealed that two of its teachers feared they caught the deadly disease from Mr Walsh.Students from Bevendean Primary School were also warned to stay away after a staff member was advised to self-isolate after coming into close contact with a coronavirus patient.Meanwhile, a second doctors surgery in the city — the Lions Dene surgery — linked to the Brighton coronavirus super-spreader, closed.Dr Catriona Greenwood is thought to be one of the two medics infected — and may have passed the bug on to patients.Dr Greenwood works as a locum at the practice which has since been shut for decontamination as officials scramble to trace patients to be testedYesterday, two medics were among four new confirmed victims of coronavirus, with a GP surgery placed in lockdown.The County Oak Medical Centre in Brighton, East Sussex, was closed while staff in hazmat suits deep cleaned the surgery.Just three miles away a University of Sussex student was rushed to hospital for tests after falling ill on campusThe new cases - three men and a woman - are all known contacts of Mr Walsh, who was diagnosed in Brighton last week, and are believed to have stayed at the same French ski resort.Mr Walsh became infected at the £,-a-night Grand Hyatt hotel in Singapore at a conference last month held by British gas analysis company Servomex.He then travelled to a French ski chalet at to Les Contamines-Montjoie for a ski-ing holiday with friends Bob and Catriona Saynor.Dad-of-two Bob Saynor is now infected along with his nine-year-old son and they are both in a French hospital.Another British expat dad who also had contact with Mr Walsh at the chalet tested positive when he ed to Majorca, Spain.Mr Walsh then flew to London from Geneva on an easyJet flight - prompting health bosses to desperately hunt for the hundreds of passengers who were on the flight.Back in England, he visited his local Hove pub, The Grenadier.Five staff members at The Grenadier Pub in Hove are currently in self-isolation at home after Mr Walsh visited the boozer between pm and pm last Saturday.A Servomex spokesman said: We are very pleased that Steve Walsh has made a full recovery. We continue to provide support to him and his family.We are working with Public Health authorities to ensure the welfare of our staff and communities and wish anyone with the virus a quick and full recovery.It comes the day after the government announced officers can now legally detain high-risk patients after one threatened to storm out of Arrowe Park Hospital on The Wirral, Merseyside.A security guard said: “One patient got drunk and threatened to leave.”And they will also be allowed to hunt and capture peoplethey may be infected. The new law was rushed through yesterday.The NHS have two quarantine sites, the other is in Milton Keynes, Bucks.The Health department yesterday declared the coronavirus outbreak a serious threat to the public.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “We are taking every possible step.”But experts say health bosses must now reveal more about the movements of the super-spreader.Professor Paul Hunter, from the University of East Anglia, said: “Patient confidentiality is important but we may now be at the point where the public’s need to know more information is greater.“It would be helpful to knowhe got a taxi straight home or got a bus and stopped off at the supermarket.Letting the public know this timeline will reassure many that they are not at risk.”Dr Andrew Freedman, an expert in infectious diseases at Cardf University, added: “It does appear the index case has passed on the infection to an unusually large number of contacts.“As such, he could be termed a ‘super-spreader’.“This may occur as a result of someone being infectious despite having few or no symptoms, meaning they are unaware they have the infection.“It can also result from someone coming into close contact with an unusually large number of people or someone carrying a larger than normal quantity of the virus.”The “case fatality ratio”for people in Hubei Province is  per cent.Outside China it is between . and . per cent, researchers from Imperial College London found.Variations in diagnosis and care across countries are likely to account for the dferent outcomes. The figures could also change as health chiefs collect better data on cases, deaths and recovery.Professor Neil Ferguson said the estimates did not “reflect underlying dferences in disease severity between countries.“All CFR estimates should be viewed cautiously as the sensitivity of surveillance of both deaths and cases in mainland China is unclear,” he said.There are now more than , confirmed cases of the virus worldwide, with over  deaths.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
